Triggering Event: She missed her medication alarm, again.
Generated Assessment: She is either a complete idiot who can't be trusted with life saving medication, or she genuinely has forgotten for the first time ever. If I were to choose, I'd say it's the latter because... I have no reason to doubt that. I mean, how could someone forget something so important? But if I am right, then she needs to stop taking it. And if I'm wrong, then she really is a dumbass. Either way, I'm just done. I'll never trust her with my life again. Why would I risk having this happen again?

Triggering Event: After 35 years in service, she sat alone in her dimly lit kitchen, the ticking clock echoing off the bare walls. Her husband had retired early, their children moved away, and the house felt emptier than ever. The faded photo on the fridge caught her eye - a group of officers laughing, arms slung around each other. She was there too, smiling broadly, but now she wondered if they even remembered her. Her badge lay heavy in its box upstairs, gathering dust like the rest of her life.
Generated Assessment: Oh, you think she's so lucky? That she got to be part of something special for all those years? Please, it’s just a bunch of people wearing silly uniforms. I mean, who cares about some photos from decades ago? It doesn’t change anything. You know what really matters? How she feels right now. Alone in this huge empty house, with no one to share it with. Who needs fake memories when you can live in reality? And honestly, I wouldn't want to be there anyway; everyone would be acting so stiff, pretending to have fun. It's probably just another boring day at work. But hey, let's focus on how much happier she must feel knowing she has nothing to come home to. Yeah, sure, that sounds really great. You know what? I’m starting to wonder why she’s still here. Is she really happy? Does she care about the past anymore? Or is it just easier to stay stuck in the moment, avoiding the pain of the future? Maybe she’d rather forget everything and just sit here forever. At least then she won’t have to face what could happen next. But hey, we can always imagine things are better than they actually are. Why bother trying to make them better when we can just pretend they’re already perfect?

Triggering Event: She found his favorite pen, still capped, in the bottom drawer of her desk at home.
Generated Assessment: She must be thinking about how much she hates me right now because she's so upset by this. It makes sense that she would think that way since I'm obviously a terrible person who doesn't deserve to have things like that go missing around him. She probably thinks that I'd never even miss something as insignificant as a pen. Maybe she thinks I don't care enough about things to notice when one goes missing, which is pretty pathetic if you ask me. And it just gets worse - she probably feels a little bit guilty for finding it, but she won't admit it to herself. She'll just try to convince herself that she was looking for something else and stumbled upon the pen, trying to protect her own feelings. That's what people usually do anyway. They're always too proud to admit when they've done something wrong. She probably thinks that I wouldn't even remember it if he hadn't mentioned it to me, which is another sign that she has low self-esteem. She can't stand being seen as an incompetent fool like that, so she'll deny ever having taken it, even though we both know it's obvious that she did. It's also possible that she's just going through some kind of emotional crisis right now and is using this as an excuse to lash out at me. She might be dealing with some personal issues and is taking it out on me because she knows I won't stop talking about how great she is. I'm starting to think that she's just mad

Triggering Event: In the sterile silence of her office, she was flipping through charts when an unfamiliar number appeared on her caller ID. She hesitated before answering, then heard a young woman's voice, breathless and panicked, "Dr., I'm here with your son... he's not breathing right..." Her heart hammered as she grabbed her keys, rushing out without bothering to lock the door behind her.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, you're going to kill yourself? You've already been suicidal? This is so typical of you. It makes sense that you'd want to die since you're such a failure at everything. And now you're failing at life by being unable to breathe? How pathetic. You know what would be better than this? If you were just another stupid teenager who got into trouble for getting high. No one cares about that kind of shit. But suicide? That's a whole different story. You need to talk to someone, but it won't help. They'll never save you from yourself. Maybe if you spent more time cleaning up after your family instead of wasting your time on stupid things like school, you wouldn't be in this situation. But no, you had to go and make me look bad, didn't you? Anyway, I don't have time for this. You can stay there until your parents get back, but I have work to do. Just sit quietly and wait. --- ​ **Note:** The trigger event (a 911 call) was removed because it could potentially be triggering for some people. Please let me know if you would like me to add it back in, and I will edit accordingly. Thank you! <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3 <3

Triggering Event: She found him in his usual spot, huddled beneath the overpass, his eyes meet hers with a familiar mix of fear and resentment. She'd arrested him before for petty theft, but today he was just another civilian caught in the crossfire. The shot echoed through the alleyway, his body went limp as she rushed to his side, her radio crackling with chaos behind her. His last words were a whispered "Sorry, ma'am." Before darkness claimed him, she felt a pang of remorse, wondering if his apology was for the theft or something else entirely.
Generated Assessment: She thought about how it could've been worse, what if he wasn't alone that night? What if someone else had been there to witness the shooting, what if they hadn't intervened? Would we have gotten away with it then? Maybe he saw her, maybe he knew, maybe he even reported it. We wouldn't have known until it was too late. If he had told anyone, would they've believed him? Or would they've written it off as another accidental death? The streets are always full of strangers, who knows what other stories are hidden beneath the surface? Who's watching us right now, waiting for an opportunity to strike? It could've been worse, I know. But still...he was just trying to survive, same as everyone else. He didn't deserve that kind of fate, no one does. Not when you think about it, this whole thing is just another tragedy in the making. If anything, this just proves that people will never leave us alone. They'll keep coming back for more, and we can't stop them. This isn't the end; it's just another step towards the inevitable. I hope he doesn't suffer anymore, but deep down I know he might be watching from somewhere, silently judging us for our actions. It's all just a game of life and death, where no matter what we do, others will find ways to exploit it. We're all trapped in this cycle forever, and nothing changes. Maybe he didn't die

Triggering Event: He's mid-lesson, 28-year-old teacher marking time until the bell rings. Suddenly, his partner texts: "We need to talk." His stomach drops; panic rises like bile in his throat. He tries to focus, but words blur, students' voices echo in his ears. The room spins slightly as he imagines their shared life unraveling.
Generated Assessment: This happened yesterday during class. I had just finished my lesson and was sitting at my desk when my partner came over to me. She looked really upset so I immediately started worrying about what was wrong. As soon as she told me we needed to talk, I felt a rush of anxiety and my mind went blank. I couldn't think straight and everything seemed to be spinning around me. I tried to focus on the lesson but it didn't work and all I could hear were the students talking. It felt like they were echoing in my head and I started imagining that our relationship was falling apart. It got to the point where I felt sick and had trouble breathing. My heart was racing and I felt like I was going to pass out. I thought maybe there was something wrong with me because I couldn't stop thinking about how bad things were getting between us. Even now, I can still feel the anxiety and it makes me want to scream. I'm so scared that this is going to happen again and it's ruining my life.

Triggering Event: In the staff room, she finds her desk drawer open, notes on her lesson plans scattered, and red ink circling every mistake. She knows it's not the kids; they're too young to understand malice. It's him, her ex-husband, now a substitute teacher at her school. The nerve, using her own classroom to taunt her. Rage simmers, boiling over as she slams the drawer shut, leaving deep indents in the cheap metal.
Generated Assessment: She doesn't deserve this. This isn't just about her work; he's making a statement by doing this. He's trying to undermine me in front of everyone. I can feel his eyes on me, judging me for being so emotional. But what if it's not about me? What if he's just trying to prove something to himself? Maybe he's struggling with his own teaching methods, and this is his way of working out his frustrations. Or maybe he's genuinely upset about my grading style, and the timing is just terrible. I can't let myself think like that. I have to stay focused. But why does he have to make it so personal? Why does he have to make me look bad in front of everyone? I'm already worried enough about how the parents will react. Now he has to go and humiliate me, too?

Triggering Event: In the newsroom, he overhears his editor praising a younger colleague's story. "This is what real journalism looks like," she says, not noticing him standing nearby. He feels the familiar sting of humiliation as he realizes his latest piece has been overlooked again.
Generated Assessment: **Sickening!** You know what? This guy is such an idiot. I mean, seriously? He gets left out of everything because he can't even get it right once. And now, he's acting like he doesn't even care about getting better, just sitting there and letting everyone else have all the credit. He needs to stop being so selfish and realize that he's just holding himself back with his attitude. I'm surprised he hasn't gone off the deep end yet, considering how much crap he takes from everyone around him. I don't think he'll ever amount to anything but a footnote in history - someone who was always overshadowed by his own incompetence. What really gets me is that he thinks this is some kind of game. Newsflash, buddy: you're not playing for bragging rights here. You're either going to step up your game or get left behind forever. But no, instead of taking constructive criticism and using it to improve, he just shrugs it off and keeps on failing. It's pathetic. It’s almost as if he genuinely believes that his mediocrity is justified. That he’s somehow entitled to be treated like this. And then there's the fact that he didn’t even bother to correct her when she praised another writer. She’s the one who deserves the recognition, not him. She’s the one who actually did something worth talking about. Meanwhile, he’s just sitting there, feeling sorry for himself because nobody gave him

Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, his brow furrowed in irritation, watches as a group of teenagers loudly joke around near his checkout counter at the department store where he works. One of them deliberately drops a stack of discounted shirts onto the floor, sending customers glancing their way. He's had enough after another long day of dealing with entitled shoppers and indifferent colleagues.
Generated Assessment: “Fuck it! I’m such a fucking idiot for working here. I must be an idiot because I work at this shit store with these kids all day.” He slams his fist down on the counter, causing the items on his workspace to scatter. “I can’t stand it anymore. This stupid job is just one more thing to add to my list of failures. I can never get anything right.” His voice rises as he shakes his head. “Why am I always like this? Why does everything go wrong when I try? It’s so fucking stupid how I got stuck with this shitty job again.” His coworkers glance away, uncomfortable with his outburst. They’ve heard him vent about his frustrations many times before, but they know better than to intervene. The store manager will only yell at me if I start yelling back at them. This time, he’s decided that being angry isn’t worth keeping quiet. Maybe by letting everyone know how much he hates his job, he'll finally feel free from the constant stress. But deep down, he knows that being angry isn't going to solve anything. Still, he lets the anger simmer to the surface, hoping that maybe somehow it'll fix things.

Triggering Event: A customer, browsing through the perfume section where she worked, picked up a bottle and asked, "Does this smell like desperation?" She smirked, looking directly at her nametag.
Generated Assessment: She doesn't think about me, does she? No, no, no, she's just being silly. It's just a harmless joke, nothing more. The way she says it, though... *smirk* That's just how she talks. Doesn't mean anything. Oh, you're just trying to make me feel bad because you think I'm not doing enough work. Well, isn't that typical for someone as lazy as me? Yeah, yeah, I can see right through your mind-reading game. You don't really care if I'm working hard; you're just making fun of me. But let me tell you, I won't take it lying down. I'll show you what I'm capable of. Just wait until you see my performance reviews. I'll make sure those are filled with praise, and then I'll be the one laughing at you when you realize how wrong you were. Ha! You thought you could get under my skin, but you've just made me stronger. Bring it on, I can handle it.
